courses.name: Introduction to Biochemistry
courses.description: Fundamental concepts in biochemistry and molecular biology: structure function relationships, reactivity, thermodynamics, gene expression.  Professional skills for biomedical careers.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1100 or MATH 1160 or MATH 1500  and Freshman or Sophomore standing

courses.name: Introductory Biochemistry Laboratory
courses.description: Techniques course involving analytical experiments with carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, nucleic acids; use of instrumentation in biochemistry; purification and kinetics of enzymes, PCR and cloning. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: The Living World: Molecular Scale
courses.description: Survey of modern biochemistry and biotechnology. Structure and function of DNA, proteins, lipids and carbohydrates. The role of biopolymers in life processes and everyday living is emphasized.

courses.name: Biotechnology in Society
courses.description: Biotechnology in a social context covers three areas: introduction to terminology and concepts, specific biotechnological applications to modern problems, and ethical questions.

courses.name: Introduction to Macromolecular Structure and Function
courses.description: The function of biochemical macromolecules is directly related to their structure.  The three-dimensional structures of proteins, nucleic acids, polysaccharides and membranes are each explored in the context of their functions and their microenvironments within living organisms.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: C- or higher in BIOCHM 1090; CHEM 2100Corequisites: CHEM 2110

courses.name: Macromolecular Techniques Laboratory
courses.description: The laboratory experiments include DNA isolation, DNA cloning, PCR, plasmid transformation, protein expression, affinity-tagged chromatography, SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, enzyme isolation, enzyme assay, buffer preparation, and Michaelis-Menten kinetics. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: sophomore standing; restricted to Biochemistry majors only

courses.name: Macromolecular Techniques Laboratory - Honors
courses.description: The laboratory experiments include DNA isolation, DNA cloning, PCR, plasmid transformation, protein expression, affinity-tagged chromatography, SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, enzyme isolation, enzyme assay, buffer preparation, and Michaelis-Menten kinetics.   Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: sophomore standing; Biochemistry majors only. Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Macromolecular Techniques Laboratory - Honors/Writing Intensive
courses.description: The laboratory experiments include DNA isolation, DNA cloning, PCR, plasmid transformation, protein expression, affinity-tagged chromatography, SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, enzyme isolation, enzyme assay, buffer preparation, and Michaelis-Menten kinetics.   Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: sophomore standing; Biochemistry majors only. Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Biochemistry
courses.description: Research for students in which independent research is less than 50% of total. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: General Biochemistry
courses.description: Survey of biochemistry; static/dynamic aspects of carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, nucleic acid. Discussion of metabolic pathways, energy production, and metabolic regulatory mechanism.

courses.name: Topics in Biochemistry
courses.description: Experimental courses; highly specialized topics taught infrequently or courses taught by visiting professors.

courses.name: Medicinal Plant Science
courses.description: Presentation of core topics, including an overview of plant groups with medicinal properties, botanical nomenclature, important biochemical pathways, exposure to journals, texts, and online databases that facilitate evidence-based research involving medicinal plants. Content of world-wide application. Has an international flavor. The course facilitates students to be independent learners and critical thinkers in this important knowledge area (of value to diverse academic backgrounds). The important role of collaborative inter-disciplinary studies will also be emphasized.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Biochemistry
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOCHM 7270). First semester of comprehensive biochemistry course: metabolic pathways, amino acids/proteins, carbohydrates, lipids, nucleic acids, kinetics, energy requirements, metabolic regulation in living cells.

courses.name: Biochemistry
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOCHM 7272). Second semester of a comprehensive biochemistry course, including metabolism of carbohydrates, fatty acids, steroids, amino acid synthesis and metabolism, molecular genetics, hormones, photosynthesis and integrated metabolism.

courses.name: Physical Chemistry of Biological Systems
courses.description: To present fundamental principles of physical chemistry in the context of the structure and function of biological macromolecules.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Computer Assisted Sequence Analysis and Molecular Modeling
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOCHM 7376). Employs the use of computer-based interactive molecular graphics and sequence analysis software to analyze the three dimensional structures of macromolecules.

courses.name: Cancer Biology
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 4460; cross-leveled with BIOCHM 7978, BIO_SC 7978).  Cancer, cell biology, genetics, biochemistry.

courses.name: Single Molecule Biophysics
courses.description: (same as PHYSCS 4510; cross-leveled with BIOCHM 7510, PHYSCS 7510). The course provides an overview of the biophysics of enzymes, nucleic acids and the cytoskeleton.  Topics covered will include diffusion, molecular motors, polymerization and the cytoskeleton and the polymer properties of nucleic acids and microtubules.

courses.name: Internship in Biochemistry
courses.description: Field-based learning experience combining study, observation, and employment with a business, organization, or governmental agency.  The internship provides opportunities to apply skills, concepts and theories about biochemistry in a practical context.  The student intern, internship supervisor, and university coordinator will develop an individualized internship plan. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Advanced Undergraduate Research in Biochemistry
courses.description: Research credit for students doing an independent research project under the guidance of a faculty member. Project must be arranged by student and faculty member prior to registration.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Industrial Internship with ABC Laboratories
courses.description: This 5-credit course is a school and field-based learning experience combining the study, observation, and employment with ABC Laboratories in Columbia, MO. The internship provides opportunities to apply skills, concepts and theories about biochemistry and analytical chemistry in a practical context. The purpose of the internship experience is to provide the intern with the opportunity to develop knowledge and skills deemed desirable for a career in the biotechnology industries. During the time indicated in this agreement for the internship experience, the intern is expected to become a productive employee of ABC Laboratories. This course will provide technical instruction on commonly used laboratory skills and instrumentation at the University of Missouri followed by technical instruction on software and instrumentation at ABC Laboratories. After the training period, the interns will have the opportunity to work at ABC Laboratories full time for the summer.

courses.name: Senior Capstone in Biochemistry
courses.description: Problem-based course on fundamental concepts of biochemistry.  Requires written and oral presentations.  One of two capstone courses required for biochemistry majors. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Biochemistry Laboratory
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOCHM 7274). Techniques course involving analytical experiments with carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, nucleic acids; use of instrumentation in biochemistry; purification and kinetics of enzymes.  One of two capstone courses required for biochemistry majors.

courses.name: Biochemistry Laboratory - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOCHM 7274). Techniques course involving analytical experiments with carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, nucleic acids; use of instrumentation in biochemistry; purification and kinetics of enzymes.  One of two capstone courses required for biochemistry majors.

courses.name: Honors Thesis Research in Biochemistry
courses.description: Laboratory research for honors students doing an honors thesis research project in their final two semesters.  Enrollment limited to Honors eligible students with senior standing who have CAFNR honors approval.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Problems in Biochemistry
courses.description: Problems in Biochemistry.
courses.prerequisites: Consent of Director of Graduate Studies required

courses.name: Maps in Medicine Summer Institute
courses.description: Lab/lecture course in which high school teachers gain knowledge of two innovative, inquiry-based programs, Mapping Health and Mapping Cell Fate, that focus on influenza and developmental biology and Missouri science standards for biology and health. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Biochemistry
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOCHM 4270). First semester of comprehensive biochemistry course: metabolic pathways, amino acids/proteins, carbohydrates, lipids, nucleic acids, kinetics, energy requirements, metabolic regulation in living cells.

courses.name: Biochemistry
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOCHM 4272). Second semester of a comprehensive biochemistry course, including metabolism of carbohydrates, fatty acids, steroids, amino acid synthesis and metabolism, molecular genetics, hormones, photosynthesis and integrated metabolism.

courses.name: Biochemistry Laboratory
courses.description: Techniques course involving analytical experiments with carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, nucleic acids; use of instrumentation in biochemistry; radioisotope tracers in metabolism; isolation, purification and kinetics of enzymes.

courses.name: Computer Assisted Sequence Analysis and Molecular Modeling
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOCHM 4376). This course uses advanced computer graphics and computational techniques to analyze protein and nucleic acid sequences and their three-dimensional structures.

courses.name: Single Molecule Biophysics
courses.description: (same as PHYSCS 7510; cross-leveled with BIOCHM 4510, PHYSCS 4510). The course provides an overview of the biophysics of enzymes, nucleic acids and the cytoskeleton.  Topics covered will include diffusion, molecular motors, polymerization and the cytoskeleton and the polymer properties of nucleic acids and microtubules.

courses.name: Cancer Biology
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 7978). The course will cover major molecular and cellular aspects of cancer. Students will read original research articles, present overviews and lead class discussions.

courses.name: Ethical Conduct of Research
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 8060). Discussion of ethical issues in biological research, including the rules and conventions for appropriate research conduct.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Research in Biochemistry
courses.description: Research in biochemistry for qualified students, with counsel of faculty. Includes preparation of dissertation. Graded on a S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Consent of Director of Graduate Studies required

courses.name: Advanced Medicinal Plant Science
courses.description: Presentation of core topics in pharmacognosy, including an overview of plant groups with medicinal properties, essentials of botanical nomenclature, Overview of pharmacological activities of plant-sourced products and evidence-based research, phytochemical variation and significance, important biochemical pathways, origins of secondary metabolites, some major groups of phytochemicals, observations on economic and social trends in the use of medicinal plant products in developed and developing countries, overview of modern technology, high throughput screening, bioinformatics. Considerable exposure to key articles in journals, based on internationally accepted text (Trease & Evans), exposure to online databases - all sources of information that facilitate evidence-based research involving medicinal plants. Content of world-wide application. Has considerable international flavor and directly applicable to medicinal flora world-wide. The course facilitates students to be independent learners and critical thinkers in this important knowledge area (of value to diverse academic backgrounds). The important role of collaborative inter-disciplinary studies is also emphasized. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 1100 or CHEM 1320 or BIOCHM 1090 and BIO_SC 1200 or BIO_SC 1500 or the equivalent of these courses for non-MU students
courses.recommendation: A Freshman level course in the Life Sciences or General Botany will also be advantageous but not essential

courses.name: Introduction to Graduate Biochemistry I
courses.description: Introduction to biochemistry for life science graduate students. Core course for Biochemistry students. Structures and interactions of biological macromolecules including thermodynamics, binding, enzyme action and biological membranes as well as techniques of analysis and structure determination.
courses.prerequisites: Undergraduate organic chemistry plus undergraduate biochemistry or molecular biology, their equivalent or permission of instructor

courses.name: Macromolecular Systems Integration
courses.description: To introduce graduate students to biochemistry at the graduate level with particular emphasis on genomics/gene expression and replication; proteomics/cell signaling and metabolism. Course graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Nutritional Biochemistry of Carbohydrates
courses.description: (same as NUTRIT 8360 and NEP 8360). Current concepts with in-depth coverage of selected examples of key regulatory steps controlling carbohydrate metabolism; emphasizing molecular mechanisms. Based entirely on research literature and taught in a tutorial format.

courses.name: Introduction to Plant Metabolism
courses.description: (same as PLNT_S 8362 and BIO_SC 8362). This course is part of a series that aims to provide a solid conceptual foundation in interdisciplinary plant biology for graduate students with a research emphasis in plant biology.  This course examines the basic concepts and techniques used to understand plant metabolism.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Introduction to Molecular Cell Biology
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 8365 and PLNT_S 8365). This course is part of a series that aims to provide a solid conceptual foundation in interdisciplinary plant biology for graduate students with a research emphasis on plant biology.  This course examines the basic concepts and techniques used to understand molecular cell biology.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Molecular Biology of Mineral Nutrition
courses.description: (same as NUTRIT 8390 and NEP 8390). Current concepts of metal ion transport, intracellular metal trafficking and metal-dependent regulation of gene expression. Based entirely on research literature and taught in a tutorial format.

courses.name: Physical Biochemistry
courses.description: Physical concepts underlying a variety of physical chemical methods as they apply to biochemical research.

courses.name: Enzymology and Metabolic Regulation
courses.description: A basic introduction to the study of enzymes and their role in intermediary metabolism. Topics include enzyme kinetics, mechanisms of enzymatic catalysis and control of metabolic pathways.

courses.name: Signaling in Molecular Cell Biology
courses.description: The objective of this course is to provide important foundations in cellular signaling in the context of biochemistry and cell biology for first and second year graduate students. The course focuses on cell-to-cell communication and intracellular signaling via different classes of cell surface receptors using specific receptor paradigms from human, other animals, plants, yeast and E.coli. Primary literature will be used for in-class discussions and homework assignments to highlight key experiments and introduce students to relevant experimental techniques. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Nutrient Regulation of Gene Expression
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 8438, NUTRIT 8438, and NEP 8438). Current concepts with in-depth coverage of several minerals that illustrate themes in molecular mineral nutrition. Based entirely on research literature and taught in a tutorial format.

courses.name: Rotation Research
courses.description: Introductory laboratory research.  Graded on A-F basis only.  Normally 1 hour per advisor per semester, two-1 hour sections can be taken per semester.

courses.name: Topics in Biochemistry
courses.description: Experimental courses, highly specialized topics taught infrequently or courses taught by visiting professors.

courses.name: Problems in Biochemistry
courses.description: Problems in Biochemistry

courses.name: Seminar in Biochemistry
courses.description: Review of current literature; individual presentation of research or classical science topics.

courses.name: Research in Biochemistry
courses.description: Research in biochemistry for qualified students, with counsel of faculty. Includes preparation of dissertation. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Molecular Biology I
courses.description: (same as MICROB 9430). Detailed examination of current fundamental concepts of molecular genetics of bacteria, bacteriophages and yeast. Experimental approaches to analysis of the physical structures of genomic nucleic acids, the biochemistry and genetics of mutations, replication, gene transfer and gene expression will be examined in depth from reports in the current literature.

courses.name: Molecular Biology II
courses.description: (same as MICROB and BIO_SC 9432) Detailed experimental analysis of eukaryotic cellular and molecular biology relevant to cellular and viral gene expression, post-transcriptional and post-translational modifications and genome replication. Models for developmental genetic analysis and genetic determinants controlling developmental processes utilizing the current literature will be examined.

courses.name: Hormone Action
courses.description: A lecture course with weekly assigned readings. Topics will include: a description of selected polypeptide, steroid and other hormones and their biological effects; receptors; second messengers; protein phosphorylation in hormone mediation; growth factors; cellular oncogenes.

courses.name: Plant Biochemistry
courses.description: Emphasizes biochemistry unique to plants; biochemical events plants share with other organisms discussed, compared. Photosynthesis, metabolism, composition, compartmentation, regulation of biochemical events included.

courses.name: Molecular Biology of Plant Growth and Development
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 9468). Molecular biology of plant hormones, signal transduction, environmental signals.

courses.name: Analytical Biochemistry--Chromatography
courses.description: Principles, experimental design, capabilities, limitations, and applications of the general field of chromatography of biologically important molecules. Eight (2-hour) lectures, eight (4-hour) labs. Four weeks.

courses.name: Analytical Biochemistry--Mass Spectrometry
courses.description: Instrumentation, fragmentation mechanisms, interpretation of spectra, combined gas chromatography--mass spectrometry. Eight (2-hour) lectures, eight (4-hour) labs.
